title: Responsive design with Bootstrap
author: Fredrik Johnsson
description: Bootstrap is a popular front-end framework for building responsive and mobile-first websites. It is open-source and free to use, making it an accessible and widely adopted choice for web development. One of the very appreciated features of Bootstrap is the grid system. This system helps you to easily create a responsive design that adapts to different screen sizes. For example can you specify how many columns a element should span on different screens. With the help of this system can you create a very advanced layout that adapts to all the different devices and you don't have to write a bunch of CSS styles. Bootstrap also comes with a number of JavaScript plugins that add functionality to your website. For example can you add all of their different components in a very easy way by looking at their documentation. There can you find very complex solutions and just by an easy copy get it into your project. One example is the Bootstrap carousel plugin that allows you to create a image carousel, where you can just by a click shift between different images. Using Bootstrap with CSS offers several benefits that make it a popular choice among developers. On big key aspect of Bootstrap is its consistent and standardized design system with SASS. This system makes it a little bit easier to creae a professional-looking layout without starting from scratch. This is particually helpful for beginners who are new to the field. To get started with Bootstrap, you can download the framework from the official website and add the CSS and JavaScript files to your web page. Once you have the framework set up, you can start using the pre-built components and utility classes to create your website. In conclusion, Bootstrap is a powerful and easy-to-use framework that can help you build responsive and visually appealing projects quickly and easily without being an expert of the field.

title: HTML - an introduction
author: Fredrik Johnsson
description: HTML, or Hypertext Markup Language, is the fundamental building block of the internet and it has been that since the early 1990s. It is a markup language that is used to create web pages and other online content that can be viewed on a variety of devices, such as computers, smartphones, and tablets. HTML is a language that is easy to learn and is used by millions of people around the world to create web pages and other online content. By using HTML tags, you can define different elements on your web page, such as headings, paragraphs, lists, images, and links. These elements can be arranged and styled using CSS, or Cascading Style Sheets, which allows you to control the layout, colors, fonts, and other design elements of your web page. One of the main advantages of HTML is that it is a platform-independent language, meaning that it can be viewed on any device that has a web browser. This makes it a versatile language that can be used for a wide range of applications, from personal blogs to e-commerce websites to online educational resources. To get started with HTML, you will need a text editor and a basic understanding of the syntax and structure of the language. HTML is a markup language, which means that it uses tags to define elements on the page. Tags are enclosed in angle brackets, <> and </>, and are used to define the beginning and end of an element. HTML is a powerful and flexible language that is essential for anyone who wants to create content for the web. Whether you are just starting out or are an experienced developer, HTML is a language that is easy to learn and can help you create beautiful and functional web pages and online content. One minor weakness with HTML is that you must add another language like JavaScript to make it functional if you want like for instance to handle data.

title: CSS - an introduction
author: Fredrik Johnsson
description: CSS, or Cascading Style Sheets, is a language that web developers use to make websites look nice. It's like the 'clothing' that you put on a web page, and it works together with HTML to create a complete and organized website. CSS has a lot of useful features. For example, you can use it to change the color, font, and layout of a web page. This means you can customize how the text looks, where it's positioned on the page, and what colors are used. One of the most important parts of CSS is 'selectors'. Selectors are like a 'targeting system' that lets you choose what part of the web page you want to style. This could be a paragraph of text, an image, or a button. Once you've selected the element you want to style, you can then apply your own rules to it. These rules are defined using 'CSS properties'. For example, you can use the 'font-size' property to change the size of the text or the 'background-color' property to change the color of the background. Another important concept in CSS is 'cascading'. This means that if you have multiple CSS rules that apply to the same element, the browser will choose the one with the highest importance. This could be because it's the most specific to that element or because it comes last in the CSS file. To get started with CSS, you need to create a new file called a 'CSS file' and link it to your HTML file using the link tag. Once you've done this, you can start defining your own styling rules using selectors and CSS properties. CSS is a very useful tool for web designers because it allows them to create visually appealing and user-friendly websites. With a bit of practice and experimentation, you can learn how to use CSS to create beautiful and functional web pages.

title: JavaScript - an introduction
author: Fredrik Johnsson
description: JavaScript is a powerful programming language that has become an essential part of web development. It is a client-side scripting language, which means it runs in the user's web browser, rather than on the server hosting the website. JavaScript is used to add interactivity and dynamic functionality to websites. It allows developers to create everything from simple drop-down menus and pop-up windows to complex web applications and video games. With JavaScript, you can build interactive user interfaces, validate user input, and retrieve data from servers. One of the primary benefits of JavaScript is that it is a versatile language that can be used in conjunction with HTML and CSS to create responsive and dynamic web pages. JavaScript code can be embedded directly into HTML documents, or it can be linked to external JavaScript files, allowing for greater control over the website's functionality and design. JavaScript has a rich and extensive library of frameworks, libraries, and tools that make it easier for developers to build web applications. Popular frameworks like Angular, React, and Vue.js provide developers with pre-built components and tools to streamline the development process. JavaScript is also widely used in the development of server-side applications, such as Node.js. This allows for the creation of highly scalable and efficient web applications that can handle a large volume of traffic. JavaScript is an essential language for web development, and its versatility and power have made it one of the most popular programming languages in use today. Whether you're a seasoned developer or just starting, JavaScript provides the tools and resources you need to create powerful and engaging web applications.

title: JavaScript - The Definitive Guide
author: David Flanagan
description: JavaScript is the programming language of the web and is used by more software developers today than any other programming language. For nearly 25 years this best seller has been the go-to guide for JavaScript programmers.

title: Coding with JavaScript For Dummies
author: C Minnick
description: Go from beginner to builder quickly with this hands-on JavaScript guide Coding with JavaScript For Dummies provides easy, hands-on instruction for anyone looking to learn this popular client-side language.

title: Eloquent Javascript
author: Marijn Haverbeke
description: JavaScript lies at the heart of almost every modern web application, from social apps like Twitter to browser-based game frameworks like Phaser and Babylon. Though simple for beginners to pick up and play with, JavaScript is a flexible, complex language that you can use to build full-scale applications.

title: JavaScript for impatient programmers
author: Dr. Axel Rauschmayer
description: This book makes JavaScript less challenging to learn for newcomers, by offering a modern view that is as consistent as possible.

title: The Truth About HTML5
author: Luke Stevens
description: This is the book that will show you what rocks in HTML5 today and what the future holds for interactivity and video now Flash is dying.

title: HTML5: The Missing Manual
author: Matthew MacDonald
description: HTML5 is more than a markup language—it's a dozen independent web standards all rolled into one. Until now, all it's been missing is a manual.

title: Smashing CSS
author: Eric Meyer
description: Smashing CSS takes you well beyond the basics, covering not only the finer points of layout and effects, but introduces you to the future with HTML5 and CSS3.

title: CSS - Pocket Reference
author: Eric Meyer
description: When you're working with CSS and need a quick answer, CSS Pocket Reference delivers. This handy, concise book provides all of the essential information you need to implement CSS on the fly.

title: Core HTML5 Canvas
author: David Geary
description: This book is a painstakingly crafted, expertly written, code-fueled, no-nonsense deep dive into HTML5 Canvas printed in full color with syntax-highlighted code listings throughout.

title: Stylin' with CSS
author: Charles Wyke-Smith
description: In this completely revised edition of his bestselling Stylin' with CSS, veteran designer and programmer Charles Wyke-Smith guides you througha comprehensive overview of designing Web pages with CSS, includinthe advanced capabilities of CSS3 that are now widely implementedcross all the major browsers.

title: Beginning HTML5 & CSS3 For Dummies
author: E Tittel
description: Your full-color, friendly guide to getting started with HTML5 and CSS3! HTML and CSS are essential tools for creating dynamic websites and help make your websites even more effective and unique. This friendly-but-straightforward guide gets you started with the basics of the latest versions of HTML and CSS: HTML5 and CSS3.

title: CSS - Cookbook
author: Christopher Schmitt
description: Learn how to solve the real problems you face with CSS. This cookbook offers hundreds of practical examples for using CSS to format your web pages, and includes code samples you can use right away.

title: UX For Dummies
author: D Chesnut
description: Get up to speed quickly on the latest in user experience strategy and design UX For Dummies is a hands-on guide to developing and implementing user experience strategy.

title: UX For Beginners
author: Joel Marsh
description: Whether you want to design apps, websites, or just have an intelligent conversation about design, these quick-and-dirty lessons are for you.

title: Get Into UX
author: Vy Alechnavicius
description: The UX field has been booming for years, and as a result, a landslide of new talent has been flooding the market. All of the newcomers want to learn user experience design or research as fast as possible and get paid professional positions.
